references: Cost Complexity.  Note that any Hâ„“superscriptğ»â„“H^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hâ„“:dâ†’c:superscriptâ„â„“â†’ğ‘‘ğ‘h^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length dğ‘‘d vector, so it is cheaper to store/transmit hâ„“superscriptâ„â„“h^{\ell}. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hâ„“,Hiâ„“â€‹Wtâ„“)}â„“=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptâ„â„“superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–â„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡â„“â„“1ğ¿\{(h^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{\ell=1}^{L}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of ğ’ªâ€‹((c+1)â€‹d)ğ’ªğ‘1ğ‘‘\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(c+1)d\bigr{)}, which is far less than the usual Oâ€‹(d2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘2O(d^{2}) cost of transmission and storage.

Cost Complexity. 
Each gtâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡â„“g_{t}^{\ell} costs ğ’ªâ€‹(câ€‹d)ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘‘\mathcal{O}(cd) to store and transmit, which is a strong improvement over the usual uplink complexity of ğ’ªâ€‹(d2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘‘2\mathcal{O}(d^{2}) and even cheaper than the sketched storage cost of ğ’ªâ€‹((c+1)â€‹d)ğ’ªğ‘1ğ‘‘\mathcal{O}((c+1)d).
Remark. The client will never directly compute giâ„“âˆˆâ„dÃ—dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–â„“superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘g_{i}^{\ell}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}. The purpose of equation equationÂ 2 is to illustrate the gradient calculation, but we first take care to show this derivative is well-defined. Assuming â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is differentiable with respect to any weight, we only need to prove that âˆ‚Râ„“â€‹Wâˆ‚Hâ„“â€‹Wsuperscriptğ‘…â„“ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ»â„“ğ‘Š\frac{\partial{R^{\ell}W}}{\partial H^{\ell}W} is computable, which is indeed the case due to the structure Hâ„“superscriptğ»â„“H^{\ell}. For any count sketch matrix Hâ€‹â„ğ»â„H\mathbb{R} and vector xğ‘¥x, if xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is bucketed by hash function hjsubscriptâ„ğ‘—h_{j}, we have that [HâŠ¤â€‹Hâ€‹x]i=Hjâ€‹iâ‹…[Hâ€‹x]jsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğ»topğ»ğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹…subscriptğ»ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptdelimited-[]ğ»ğ‘¥ğ‘—[H^{\top}Hx]_{i}=H_{ji}\cdot[Hx]_{j}, therefore, the partial derivative âˆ‚Râ„“â€‹Wâˆ‚Hâ„“â€‹Wsuperscriptğ‘…â„“ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ»â„“ğ‘Š\frac{\partial{R^{\ell}W}}{\partial H^{\ell}W} is well-defined. In practice, the client will use an autograd-like library.

In general, Comfetch models are competitive against uncompressed FedAvg training in CIFAR10/100 training. CIFAR-10 model performance is presented in Table 1 and and Figures 2 and 3. For iid settings, 50% sketched compression results in a test accuracy drop off of <2%absentpercent2<2\%, while 75% compression results in decreased accuracy of <4%absentpercent4<4\%. We begin to notice a significant decline at 90%percent9090\% compression, which appears to be a general threshold across all experiments. Non-iid training appears to be slightly more challenging, but nonetheless, our Comfetch models mimic the performance of un-sketched models with minimal dropoff for compression rates up to 75%percent7575\%.

CIFAR-100 training, displayed in Table 2 and the bottom series of Figures 2 and 3, is far more challenging. However, our models still display competitive performance against non-sketched training for models with up to 75%percent7575\%, regardless of iid or non-iid training.

The Count Sketch data structure contains a collection of kğ‘˜k pairwise-independent hashing maps hi:[d]â†’[c]:subscriptâ„ğ‘–â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ‘h_{i}:[d]\rightarrow[c] for iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k], each of which is paired with a sign map si:[d]â†’{Â±1}:subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘plus-or-minus1s_{i}:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\}, for iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k]. Each hash function/sign map pair is used to project a dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector xğ‘¥x into cğ‘c-dimensional space, which we refer to as a sketch. Furthermore, we refer to cğ‘c as the sketching length and kğ‘˜k as the number of the sketches. Each of the kğ‘˜k sketches is representable as a linear transformation Hiâ€‹xâˆˆâ„csubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘H_{i}x\in\mathbb{R}^{c} for iâˆˆ[k]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘˜i\in[k], where Hiâˆˆâ„cÃ—dsubscriptğ»ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘H_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{c\times d} is referred to as a Count Sketch matrix. To â€œunsketchâ€ or restore a sketch back to dğ‘‘d-dimensional space, we simply multiply by the transpose of Hisubscriptğ»ğ‘–H_{i}, i.e., x^i=HiâŠ¤â€‹Hiâ€‹xâˆˆâ„dsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–topsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\hat{x}_{i}=H_{i}^{\top}H_{i}x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where we use the hat notation to specifically indicate that x^isubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–\hat{x}_{i} is merely an approximation of xğ‘¥x. The final approximation x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} of xğ‘¥x is determined coordinate-wise as (x^)j=median1â‰¤iâ‰¤kâ€‹{x^i}i=1ksubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘—1ğ‘–ğ‘˜mediansuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘˜(\hat{x})_{j}=\underset{1\leq i\leq k}{\textrm{median}}\{\hat{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} for jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d].

As detailed in the previous section, each sketch has a matrix representation which we will now make explicit. Let h:[d]â†’[c]:â„â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ‘h:[d]\rightarrow[c] and s:[d]â†’{Â±1}:ğ‘ â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘plus-or-minus1s:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\} be a hash function/sign pair. The associated count sketch matrix Hğ»H is representable as the following cÃ—dğ‘ğ‘‘c\times d matrix transformation: fixing iâˆˆ[c]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[c] and jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d], we have that (H)iâ€‹j=sâ€‹(i)subscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘–(H)_{ij}=s(i) if hâ€‹(j)=iâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–h(j)=i for jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d] and 0 otherwise.

We note that kğ‘˜k corresponds to the number of independent sketches, which is required theoretically to achieve a guarantee on approximating Wtâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡â„“W_{t}^{\ell}, but in practice, we observe in Section 6 that one sketch is sufficient for model convergence. Also note that any Hiâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–â„“H_{i}^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hiâ„“:dâ†’c:superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–â„“â†’ğ‘‘ğ‘h_{i}^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length dğ‘‘d vector. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hiâ„“,Hiâ„“â€‹Wtâ„“)}i=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–â„“superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–â„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡â„“ğ‘–1ğ‘˜\{(h_{i}^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{i=1}^{k}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of ğ’ªâ€‹((kâ€‹c+1)â€‹d)ğ’ªğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘‘\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(kc+1)d\bigr{)}, which in the one-sketch (k=1ğ‘˜1k=1) case is less than the Oâ€‹(d2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘2O(d^{2}) cost of transmitting the full weight.

In this section, we present additional data in Table 3 and Figure 5 for language tasks not included in the main paper. The results demonstrate that our Comfetch preserves accuracy while reducing the size of weights in gates of the LSTM layer by different ratios. We maintain a high test accuracy while reducing the number of parameters from 9607 to 2439. We exclude embedding parameters from the overall parameter counts as they serve as inputs and can be pre-trained.

In Table 4, we conduct a simple study examining how Comfetch compression affects single (unfederated) client training when ResNet-9 is used to train over CIFAR-10 over 25 epochs. We additionally conduct random pruning of a non-sketched model to mimic compression. Fixed random pruning to achieve the same compression amount outputs worse models. It is important to note that pruning works well for pre-trained models, but this study demonstrates the ineffectiveness of one-time pruning prior to training. Figure 2 demonstrates the training and test curves.

Comfetch 90% 43.80 42.52

Comfetch 50% 54.76 52.89
No Compression 0% 57.16 55.21

To â€œunsketchâ€ or restore a sketch back to dğ‘‘d-dimensional space, we simply multiply by the transpose of Hisubscriptğ»ğ‘–H_{i}, i.e., x^i=HiâŠ¤â€‹Hiâ€‹xâˆˆâ„dsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–topsubscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\hat{x}_{i}=H_{i}^{\top}H_{i}x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where we use the hat notation to specifically indicate that x^isubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–\hat{x}_{i} is merely an approximation of xğ‘¥x. The final approximation x^^ğ‘¥\hat{x} of xğ‘¥x is determined coordinate-wise as (x^)j=median1â‰¤iâ‰¤kâ€‹{x^i}i=1ksubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘—1ğ‘–ğ‘˜mediansuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘˜(\hat{x})_{j}=\underset{1\leq i\leq k}{\textrm{median}}\{\hat{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} for jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d].

As detailed in the previous section, each sketch has a matrix representation which we will now make explicit. Let h:[d]â†’[c]:â„â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ‘h:[d]\rightarrow[c] and s:[d]â†’{Â±1}:ğ‘ â†’delimited-[]ğ‘‘plus-or-minus1s:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\} be a hash function/sign pair. The associated count sketch matrix Hğ»H is representable as the following cÃ—dğ‘ğ‘‘c\times d matrix transformation: fixing iâˆˆ[c]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[c] and jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d], we have that (H)iâ€‹j=sâ€‹(i)subscriptğ»ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ ğ‘–(H)_{ij}=s(i) if hâ€‹(j)=iâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–h(j)=i for jâˆˆ[d]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‘j\in[d] and 0 otherwise.

We note that kğ‘˜k corresponds to the number of independent sketches, which is required theoretically to achieve a guarantee on approximating Wtâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡â„“W_{t}^{\ell}, but in practice, we observe in Section 6 that one sketch is sufficient for model convergence. Also note that any Hiâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–â„“H_{i}^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hiâ„“:dâ†’c:superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–â„“â†’ğ‘‘ğ‘h_{i}^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length dğ‘‘d vector. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hiâ„“,Hiâ„“â€‹Wtâ„“)}i=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–â„“superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘–â„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡â„“ğ‘–1ğ‘˜\{(h_{i}^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{i=1}^{k}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of ğ’ªâ€‹((kâ€‹c+1)â€‹d)ğ’ªğ‘˜ğ‘1ğ‘‘\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(kc+1)d\bigr{)}, which in the one-sketch (k=1ğ‘˜1k=1) case is less than the Oâ€‹(d2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‘2O(d^{2}) cost of transmitting the full weight.

In this section, we present additional data in Table 3 and Figure 5 for language tasks not included in the main paper. The results demonstrate that our Comfetch preserves accuracy while reducing the size of weights in gates of the LSTM layer by different ratios. We maintain a high test accuracy while reducing the number of parameters from 9607 to 2439. We exclude embedding parameters from the overall parameter counts as they serve as inputs and can be pre-trained.

In Table 4, we conduct a simple study examining how Comfetch compression affects single (unfederated) client training when ResNet-9 is used to train over CIFAR-10 over 25 epochs. We additionally conduct random pruning of a non-sketched model to mimic compression. Fixed random pruning to achieve the same compression amount outputs worse models. It is important to note that pruning works well for pre-trained models, but this study demonstrates the ineffectiveness of one-time pruning prior to training. Figure 2 demonstrates the training and test curves.
